editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
BE plea≈øed to take notice, that here is pre≈øented to publike view, the true legitimate birth of the Authour, who≈øe name it beares. He left ≈øeverall Sermons under his owne hand, preached at ≈øpeciall times, and in Auditories of greate≈øt worth and e≈øtimation, the chiefe of which are now made publike, in the≈øe en≈øuing Sermons: other of his Sermons were onely taken from his mouth, in the publi≈øhing of which, the be≈øt care is and ≈øhall be taken, to publi≈øh them by, and compare them with the exacte≈øt copies that can be gotten. In both you have the Authours mind, as neare as can be, expre≈ø≈øed, in his own words, without adding or detracting. In the latter, you ≈øhall finde the heads of the Sermons (which were all that were la≈øt perfected by the Authour) in a methodicall Analy≈øis prefixed before them: they were his owne, both for forme and words; onely what he wrote in Latine, is tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh, for the benefit of all, and the Latine you ≈øhall have in≈øerted in the margin, in his own words, an≈øwerable to the ≈øeverall particulars treated on in the Sermons: you may ≈øee a proofe of it in the Sermon upon 1 Sam.
2. 30. if it had been ≈øooner thought on, you ≈øhould have found the like in all, you may expect it in the re≈øt, except in ≈øome few, which are already in the Pre≈ø≈øe, or prepared for it. This ≈øhall be the token in every Sermon, by which the true birth ≈øhall be di≈øtingui≈øhed from ≈øuch counterfeits, as might otherwi≈øe be fathered upon him. Be intreated to pardon the ≈ølips of the pen in writing, and of the Pre≈ø≈øe in printing, and then I hope you ≈øhall not finde any materiall imperfections: ≈øo I commend the≈øe labours, together with thy ≈øelfe, to the ble≈øsing of God.

div.p:
I Purpo≈øed to have entred into the≈øe words abruptly; but the fir≈øt words which ≈øtand as it were in the porch, being particles of ≈øpeciall inference from the former, and therefore of nece≈ø≈øary reference to them, tell me that I mu≈øt borrow light at the next doore, that I may walke inoffen≈øively. To give a touch then of the coherence. You may take notice of it, either as they depend upon the next ver≈øes immediately going before, or as they ≈øtand in the whole building, and are as it were woven
into the whole frame of the Apo≈øtles di≈øcour≈øe. The connexion with the precedent ver≈øes is very ea≈øie and per≈øpicuous: you may areed the meaning, if you will but read the words, And all things are of God, &c. the≈øe are the words out of which you may ea≈øily draw, and (with a little turning of the wheele of your under≈øtanding) as it were ≈øpin the words that I have read, thus: We have a commi≈øsion to preach the word of reconciliation, that is the good will of God, for reconciling man to him≈øelfe by the bloud of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: We have ≈øuch a commi≈øsion from God: Ergo, we are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt. But there is ≈øomething more difficulty to ob≈øerve how the≈øe make to the generall end and ≈øcope of the Apo≈øtle: give me leave to go back a little, and take the advantage of a run, that I may the better open the meaning of the≈øe words. The faithfull Apo≈øtle (as it is the condition of all that will be faithfull) met with many rubs and much oppo≈øition at Corinth, e≈øpecially from the Colledge of proud Phari≈øees and learned Rabbins among them: among other things, his afflictions were laid in his di≈øh, and that ≈øcandall of the meanene≈ø≈øe of his per≈øon, was interpreted as a reall prejudice again≈øt the truth of his profe≈ø≈øion. You will ≈øay, a bruti≈øh collection, and again≈øt a common rule of humanity; and yet, to ≈øay truth, it is the common opinion of carnall men; they judge of Religion by the≈øe
outward impertinencies, rather than appurtenances, they cannot fancy the truth, becau≈øe of the ragged garment that ≈øhe weares. As on the contrary, the tyrant boa≈øted that the Gods approved of his ≈øacriledge, becau≈øe he ≈øailed home with a faire gale of wind: Foelix ≈øcelus virtus vocatur, Mi≈øchief happy in the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe is called vertue: and with the Papi≈øts, the o≈øtentation of the pro≈øperity of their e≈øtate, is the be≈øt demon≈øtration of the ≈øincerity of their religion: belike they have clipt the wings of pro≈øperity (as the Athenians did the wings of victory) that ≈øhe cannot flie away from their Church: ≈øo in this, Iobs friends rea≈øon thus, ≈øurely thou art an hypocrite, or el≈øe thou had≈øt never come to this: And the Barbarians in the Acts conclude thus in their countrey barbarous Mood and Figure, when they ≈øaw a viper upon Pauls hand,Acts 28. 4. ≈øurely that man is a malefactor, ju≈øtice pur≈øues him, and that vermin, as an officer of ju≈øtice, hath arre≈øted him. So do they of Corinth, according to their barbarous divinity, ≈øeeing Pauls mi≈øery, as they conceived it, call his mini≈øtery into que≈øtion: But the Apostle wipes away both the≈øe imputations, the one ca≈øt upon his per≈øon, the other on his calling, with one an≈øwer, and ≈øtops two gaps with one bu≈øh, looke 4. Chap. 7. Ver≈ø. But we have this trea≈øure in earthen ve≈ø≈øels, that the excellency of the power may be of God, and not of us. As if he ≈øhould have ≈øaid, our profe≈ø≈øion is honourable,
though our per≈øon be contemptible; our Mini≈øtery is a trea≈øure, though we Mini≈øters be but earthen ve≈ø≈øels; and the≈øe very earthen ve≈ø≈øells, though they have but a ba≈øe matter, yet they have a ble≈ø≈øed end: for they proclaim to all the world, that the excellency of the power is of God, and not of us. Is it thus, might ≈øome man ≈øay, and is there nothing then that comes to your ≈øhare? have you nothing but your labour for your paines? is there nothing to be gotten by the Go≈øpell but blowes and per≈øecution? Why then you may take all the gaines, and put them in your eye (as we u≈øe to ≈øpeake) and ≈øee never a whit the wor≈øe, and then weep them out againe. But I wonder what makes you ≈øo faithfull in ≈øuch a fruitle≈ø≈øe thing? why are you ≈øo hot for that which yeelds ≈øuch cold recompence? The Apo≈øtle, be≈øides the excellency of his function, alledges three rea≈øons why afflictions did not daunt him, and da≈øh him out of countenance, but he held on his cour≈øe and diligence in publi≈øhing the Go≈øpell: I will but point them out and pa≈ø≈øe them over.
1. From the hope of a ble≈ø≈øed reward in heaven, from the 13. Ver≈øe of the 4. Chapter to the 10. of this 5.

2. From the feare of ju≈øt puni≈øhment, and a cur≈øe, if he ≈øhould have done the worke of the Lord negligently, in the 10. and 11. Ver≈øe of this Chapter, For we mu≈øt all appeare, &c. and though here were weight enough to ≈øet the
mo≈øt ru≈øty wheeles a going: yet becau≈øe the≈øe two may work in ba≈øe minds, and are in them≈øelves but ≈øini≈øter ends, which many that ≈øeem to goe ≈øtreight, may looke a ≈øquint upon: feare in the foreward, and reward and hope in the rereward mar≈øhall all his forces, and love in the maine battell, or rather, tota in toto & tota in qualibet parte, animates every one to valour and victory; puni≈øhment is ≈øervile, and hope of reward mercenary. He addes a third motive, which is the peculiar character of a Chri≈øtian mind, and that is love, in the 14 ver≈ø. of this Chap. For the love of Chri≈øt con≈øtraineth us, this is that which winds up his affections to that intention of zeal and fervencie. And I pray mark the words. Reward hath an attractive, and puni≈øhment an impul≈øive, but love hath a compul≈øive facultie. Reward drawes him, puni≈øhment drives him, but love hales him forward, to the di≈øcharge of his duty: Hope like a tender Mother entices him with a reward, feare like a ≈øevere Ma≈øter incites him with puni≈øhment, but love like a Soveraigne Lord commands him. Hope hales before him, and feare blowes behind him, and both on each ≈øide row him, but love within him like the very ≈øoule of obedience teaches him a naturall motion. Behold againe a ≈øtrange agreement, force and freedome, violent and voluntary, nece≈ø≈øity and liberty met together, and married; and which is more, the mo≈øt pure liberty with the mo≈øt
powerfull nece≈ø≈øity, For the love of Chri≈øt con≈øtraineth us, the ≈øweete≈øt natured affection. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . You ≈øee three goodly threads, which twi≈øted all together have ≈øtrength enough to draw the mo≈øt ≈øleepy ≈øluggard out of his bed of ≈øloath, but you doe not ≈øee how they are fa≈øtened to Paul, you ≈øee three mighty engines, which are able to moove him that were immovable, but you do not ≈øee in what point they touch our Apo≈øtle, and yet that is the principall point: for if the≈øe generalities were ≈øufficient, why doth not every Vzzah lay hands upon the Arke of God without any checke of ju≈øtice? why doth not every man that is not a ≈øtocke or a Stoick, that hath any hope or feare or love, become a Preacher, a publi≈øher of the Go≈øpell? humble manner, we pray you be ye reconciled to God. I have made bold to crop the≈øe few tops of flowers out of this Divine Garden which lies before my text, where I mu≈øt dwell ≈øomething longer, and I meane to ≈øcruze the juyce of them into my following di≈øcour≈øe. We pray you in Christs ≈øtead be ye reconciled to God. I ≈øhall not be curious in laying out the parts, a popular argument will be content with a popular di≈øtribution, I will but let the words fall into your eares and they will breake them≈øelves into two parts. Now therefore we are Amba≈ø≈øadors
for Chri≈øt, as though God did be≈øeech you by us, we pray you be ye reconciled to God. You ≈øee the words of their owne accord fall into two parts. 1. Yee have the Amba≈ø≈øadors, 2. The Emba≈ø≈øage: The Amba≈ø≈øadors in the fir≈øt words, We are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt, The Emba≈ø≈øage in the re≈øt; and then the la≈øt words of the fir≈øt part [for Christ] are as it were the corner ≈øtone, in which the two buildings are coupled; the middle ring, in which the two extreames are joyned; the communis terminus, in which the two parts are continued; the joynts upon which they turne them≈øelves, and cla≈øp one with another: and perhaps I may expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame thing in better termes, if I call the fir≈øt the charge, the ≈øecond the di≈øcharge; the fir≈øt, the in≈øtitution of an Office; the ≈øecond, the execution of it: In the fir≈øt, we have one Propo≈øition con≈øi≈øting of a ≈øimple antecedent, and a triple con≈øequent; the antecedent We, we are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt: the primary con≈øequent is Amba≈ø≈øadors; We are Amba≈ø≈øadors, which is attended with a double illu≈øtration, and ≈øo altogether make a treble attribution, as I told you: Fir≈øt from the Object about which they are employed, for Chri≈øt; We are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt: The ≈øecond from the Author, by whom they are imployed, from God; We are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt from God: indeed this is implyed in the text, but mu≈øt be ≈øupplyed out of the context,

This is the fir≈øt part, and the ≈øecond is like unto it, as our Saviour ≈øaid of the Commandements: for there we have one propo≈øition likewi≈øe, which hath a ≈øen≈øible proportion with the former, but yet accompanied with ≈øome remarkable alterations: for, 1. That which was the con≈øequent before hath ≈øhifted his place, and is now become the antecedent, the whole being enriched with a new con≈øequent, which was not in the former. 3. And now thus it is; We are Amba≈ø≈øadors for Chri≈øt from God, ther's the antecedent, peeced out with the three parts of the former con≈øequent: pray you be ye reconciled to God, ther's the con≈øequent, but the order of the parts are inverted: for they ≈øhould run as I propounded them, but they are propounded ≈øo, that they run cleane backward in a

So that ye have in the≈øe words two propo≈øitions, like two Semicircles, and we is the Center upon which they both move; like two Hemi≈øphears, and we is the Horizon, which divides the ≈øuperiour from the inferiour; both which together make one ≈øolid Globe, and we is the Diameter, that cuts it into equall portions, a Semicircle of being, and a Semicircle of operation; an Hemi≈øphear of office, and an Hemi≈øphear of action: The fir≈øt, We are Amba≈ø≈øadors for God, The ≈øecond, We as Amba≈øsadors pray you to be reconciled to God. This word be≈øides the particular appropriation which it hath to Paul him≈øelfe, mu≈øt needs be interpreted, according to the true propriety of the number, and meaning; and ≈øo it extends it ≈øelfe. 1. To all the Apo≈øtles. 2. To all Mini≈øters of the Word, both of them are Amba≈ø≈øadors, for they agree in the ≈øub≈øtance of their commi≈ø≈øion, though there be ≈øome difference in the circum≈øtance of the execution: the Apo≈øtolike office, indeed, carried a more lively re≈øemblance of an Amba≈ø≈øage, then the ordinary Mini≈øtery, in two regards. 1. They were authorized by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, and ≈øo received their in≈øtructions immediately from his mouth, who is the King of
the Church; and accordingly were furni≈øhed with all ≈øufficiencies, by the in≈øpiration of his Spirit; they be≈øtowed not much time and travaile to ≈øpeake forreine languages, (a thing nece≈ø≈øary for Amba≈ø≈øadors) but as E≈øaie's tongue was touched by a Seraphim with a cole from the Altar, ≈øo they had cloven and fiery tongues, be≈øtowed on them by the Spirit: be≈øide that, they had the gift of miracles, as it were the broad ≈øeale of Heaven, annexed to their letters of credit. As they had a more authenticall mi≈ø≈øion, ≈øo they had a motion more ob≈øervable, which addes as it were life and ≈øpirit to the image, and picture of Amba≈ø≈øadors. They were di≈øpatched into all coa≈øts and corners of the world; but ours are fa≈øtned to ≈øome one place, like pillars of re≈øidence; but notwith≈øtanding the≈øe petty differences, ≈øeeing they have the ≈øame ≈øphear of activity, in which they moove, to reconcile men to God, and the ≈øame Sun of authority, by which they moove,
the power of the Church, being the power of Chri≈øt derived to her, (as we call them the Kings officers, who are created not immediately by his Maje≈øtie, but in vertue of his power and in ≈øubordination to his Royall prerogative) And la≈øtly, ≈øeeing the ≈øimilitude may be pre≈øerved entire in both, though this variety be confe≈ø≈øed: there being a difference in the type Amba≈ø≈øadors, much like that in the antitype of Mini≈øters; ≈øo that either may an≈øwer the patterne: And our ordinary Mini≈øters ≈øute with agents or leiger Amba≈ø≈øadors, as the Apo≈øtles came neerer to extraordinary. In all the≈øe re≈øpects they al≈øo being included, the whole extent of this word We hath three degrees: 1. Him≈øelfe, 2. All his fellow Apo≈øtles, 3. All his fellow-labourers in the Lords harve≈øt. I have made ≈øome ha≈øte, but the time I feare hath over runne me much, and therefore for that which is behind of the explication, I will lay downe but the rude lineaments, and proportion, and leave the perfect colours and complexion to another time. The ≈øecond word (Amba≈ø≈øadors) is a ≈øpeech borrowed from Princes Courts, and applyed to Chri≈øt his Church, by a decent analogy. Amba≈ø≈øadors are me≈ø≈øengers from one Prince or State to another, about ≈øuch affaires as concerne both. You may ob≈øerve three moments of being, in this rude de≈øcription; and accordingly draw out three paralell lines, in which,
the termes of compari≈øon do runne along one by another in a ≈øweet proportion. 1. They are both Me≈ø≈øengers. 2. They are both from Princes. 3. They are both about matters of mutuall behoofe.

But, becau≈øe you know a ≈øimilitude is a tender thing, and mu≈øt be gently handled, you mu≈øt not ≈øqueize it too much, and ≈øtretch it too farre, le≈øt you breake the harmony and analogy, the Mu≈øicke and Logicke of the parts; I ≈øhall pray you to carry along with you three maine di≈øcords in which they jarre, lea≈øt promi≈øing your ≈øelves an harmony, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in every note and point; you be offended too much with every har≈øhne≈ø≈øe and inequality. 1. Amba≈ø≈øadors are therefore ≈øent from Princes, becau≈øe them ≈øelves cannot be pre≈øent every where: but the Lord of the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors, as he is in no predicament of time, becau≈øe he inhabiteth eternity; ≈øo he is in no vbi, but ubiquity. 2. Amba≈ø≈øadors are directed to Princes only, or free E≈øtates, and that from ≈øome Peere, who can neither claime ≈øubjection of them, nor ≈øuperioritie over them to whom he ≈øends. But the≈øe are ≈øent to ≈øubjects, to va≈ø≈øalls, to rebels; from him, to whom all owe an oath of allegiance; to who≈øe ≈øupremacy, the highe≈øt mu≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe; to who≈øe ≈øoveraigntie, all the ≈øonnes of the mighty are obnoxious in a politicall, naturall, e≈ø≈øentiall order of dependance. 3. Amba≈ø≈øadors are ≈øet forth
with ≈øome be≈øeeming port and pompe, that they may ≈øu≈øtaine the per≈øon of maje≈øtie, and ≈øupport the maje≈øtie of the per≈øon, whom they repre≈øent. But with the≈øe it is nothing ≈øo, the Chariots of their glory, are the ≈øhame of their Lords hou≈øe, who, to ≈øpeak with reverence, is like ≈øome rich Gentleman in the Countrey, who in a bravery, ≈øcornes to bee brave. The third word of the Text remaines, [for Chri≈øt] which may beare a threefold con≈øtruction: wherein Christ may be conceived, either, as the author, or the end, the Alpha and Omega of this Amba≈ø≈øage, or thirdly, the object of the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors, the center, and circumference of their imployment. But I promi≈øed but a delineation of the≈øe things: only give me leave to clo≈øe up all, with one ob≈øervation out of the words: I noted before that this ≈øentence [We are Amba≈ø≈øadors] is clo≈øer tru≈ø≈øed up in the Originall, into one word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a word of a precious empha≈øis, which is much abated, and very dilute, almo≈øt lo≈øt in the tran≈ølation; for that word of action, ≈øignifying the office, may tell us ≈øo much in our eares, that tho≈øe officers mu≈øt be men of action, they mu≈øt be of a nimble and active con≈øtitution. The men of the earth may be of a more dull and ≈øad temper, they may fold their armes, they may ≈øtretch them≈øelves upon their beds of Ivory, and turne them≈øelves upon them, as the doore turnes upon the hinges: But the≈øe Me≈ø≈øengers
of Heaven, mu≈øt be like Heaven in perpetuall motion: They may well fall to a motus trepidationis, if they but once forget their daily progre≈ø≈øe. They that preach Chri≈øt the Sonne of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt be like the Sunne, who commeth forth of his chamber, like a bridegroome, and rejoyceth to runne his race, as a mighty man; and yet when they have done all, there will be many ≈øonnes of darkne≈ø≈øe, that will live in a night of ≈øecurity, and ≈øleepe and ≈ønort in ≈øinne: there will be many cold profe≈ø≈øors, that are frozen to their lu≈øts, and will not be thawed by that Divine Lamp, and melted into the teares of true repentance. And therefore this tran≈ølation, We are Amba≈ø≈øadors, nimis lentum e≈øt: We ergo Amba≈ø≈øadors, hoc quoque e≈øt nimis lentum. The≈øe Mini≈øters mu≈øt fly, like the Cherubims that give attendance in the pre≈øence of God, they mu≈øt have ≈øixe winges for expedition, in the execution of his will: they have wings upon their feet, a ≈øtrange thing, wings upon their feet; no they cannot foot it fa≈øt enough, but they mu≈øt ≈øpeed their race with flight, remis vel√≠≈øque, the booke they carry, is ≈øuch as the Prophet ≈øaw, a flying booke; and Christ him≈øelfe in their mini≈øtery, ≈øitteth betweene the Cherubims, and rideth upon the wings of the winde, and ≈øo communicates him≈øelfe to all Nations.

YOU may remember, that I proceeded thus farre the la≈øt time, to lay downe the coherence of the≈øe words, with the former, and to lay open the particulars in them contained. The fir≈øt point of Doctrine, that we ≈øtarted then, was, That Mini≈øters of the Word, are Gods Amba≈ø≈øadors. I touched lightly both the circum≈øtantiall differences, which might be objected; and the ≈øub≈øtantiall agreement, which mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, as it was intended, in this metaphoricall ≈øpeech; and there we coupled
up. And though I determined then, to have gone overthem more fully, yet becau≈øe I fore≈øee many things to be delivered, I will rather pa≈ø≈øe them over; contenting my ≈øelfe, with that which hath beene ≈øpoken, and de≈øcend to the confirmation of the truth propounded. But there is one thing cro≈ø≈øes the way, and comes betweene me and my purpo≈øe: For, perhaps there are ≈øome here, who con≈øidering the name and nature of this exerci≈øe, will demand, or rather, command and challenge the re≈øolution of a que≈øtion, before I goe any farther. For what nece≈ø≈øity can be imagined, that God ≈øhould ≈øend his Amba≈ø≈øadors to us; or, if that be ≈øuppo≈øed, what conveniency may be conceived, that men, and meane men ≈øhould be imployed in ≈øo honourable a ≈øervice? To the fir≈øt part of the que≈øtion, I ≈øhall ≈øhape an an≈øwer briefly. Looke as ≈øome royall King, when his naturall ≈øubjects, have unnaturally rebelled, and taken up armes again≈øt him; (like the churli≈øh I≈øraelites, We have no portion in David, no inheritance in the ≈øonne of I≈øhai, every man to his tents O I≈ørael.) that he may curb their in≈øolencie, with the bridle of Soveraigne authority; is ready to ≈øend forth a decree of wrath, by the hand of the me≈ø≈øengers of death: But the young Prince, out of his ≈øpeciall grace and princely compa≈ø≈øion, ≈øtepping betweene them and the blow, and interceeding for them, is intreated to rever≈øe the ≈øentence, and di≈øpatch
a Proclamation of pardon, to all ≈øuch of them as within the prefixed period ≈øhall return to their obedience: So we having committed high trea≈øon, again≈øt the mo≈øt High, in mo≈øt ungracious manner, and lifted up the hand again≈øt our Maker (like the proud tyrant that belched forththis, Who is God, that we ≈øhould obey him? or who is the Lord, that we ≈øhould ≈øerve him?) who≈øe hands had but even then fa≈øhioned us; and the decree of death being gone forth again≈øt us, Thou ≈øhalt dye the death; Chri≈øt Ie≈øus the eternall Sonne of God, the Prince of peace, hath interpo≈øed him≈øelfe for us, and latched the blow (that would have ≈øunk us to Hell) upon his owne body, which he gave for us on the Cro≈ø≈øe; that ≈øo reconciliation being made in his blood, the Father might be well plea≈øed in him, to ≈øpeake peace unto us, and proclaime a free pardon to all that ≈øhould believe, by the ≈øilver Trumpet of the Go≈øpell: Returne, returne, for why will ye die √¥ hou≈øe of I≈ørael? This is the nece≈ø≈øity: wherein you may ob≈øerve on mans part, no meritorious excellencies, but mi≈øerable extremity: On Gods part, no forcible compul≈øion, but a mo≈øt feeling and free compa≈ø≈øion, that cau≈øed him to vi≈øite us, with the≈øe comfortable me≈ø≈øengers. IT is reported of a Saracen Amba≈ø≈øador to Charles the Great, that ≈øitting in the Emperors Hall at dinner with him, and ob≈øerving two tables full of gue≈øts; the lower, of poore people (invited according to his accu≈øtomed manner) in ragged weeds and ≈øimple apparell; he asked what they were: the Emperor an≈øwered; The≈øe are the Servants of our God, whom we Chri≈øtians wor≈øhip, and I entertaine them for his ≈øake: the upper, full of gallants, Courtiers in gold chains, and gay attire:

And yet I thinke I may take occa≈øion here, to take away all occa≈øion of doubting, that may perhaps ari≈øe in ≈øome weake judgements. And therefore having cleared this the la≈øt time, why God made choi≈øe of meane men for this honourable office, rather then of

The ground of this is plaine (as I touched al≈øo before) for this great world, is a little Kingdome, wherein‚ñ™ God is the ≈øoveraign Lord, the King of Kings, and all men for their po≈ø≈øie≈ø≈øions, are his tenants; for their functions, his Lievtenants; and in this great world, the little flock of Chri≈øt is a great family, in which, God is the great Ma≈øter of the family. And the ≈øame Apo≈øtle, in the la≈øt of the Ephe≈øians u≈øeth the ≈øame word to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, Eph. 20. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Yet ≈øuffer me now (according to promi≈øe) for the further clearing of this, to adde a few probable demon≈øtrations, (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake without a Soloeci≈øme) and becau≈øe the Doctrine is the be≈øt, and true≈øt

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Antiquitie is neere a Deitie: to conclude, I thinke, that true antiquitie in any Doctrine, argues the author of it to be time, that is the ancient of daies: I am ≈øure it is ≈øo here, for though I find it not recorded in Polydore

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . You Graecians are alwayes children; and to another Doctor, thou art but of ye≈øterday, but the Word of God endureth for ever, as God the Word is ye≈øterday and to day and for ever the ≈øame, from eternitie to eternitie.

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Know thy ≈øelfe.

It is the ≈øalvation of man, the mo≈øt noble and nece≈ø≈øary worke in all the world, and mo≈øt be≈øeeming the greatne≈ø≈øe, and goodne≈ø≈øe, and wi≈ødome of God, to take into his ≈øpeciall con≈øideration and providence, man being his

And if I would give you a ≈øhort draught of ≈øome truths, as they have degenerated into fables, among the Heathen, I might make them ≈øeeme with oce labour more per≈øpicuous, and more precious: for as their unlikene≈ø≈øe to them≈øelves (cro≈ø≈øing and thwarting one another) confute them≈øelves: ≈øo their likene≈ø≈øe to the truth, (intimating and as it were acting it) mu≈øt needs confirme the truth. It is mo≈øt ba≈øe for Gods Amba≈ø≈øadors, which repre≈øent his per≈øon, to pick feathers off from great Mens coates, (an ancient character of a Para≈øite) to ≈øtuffe pillowes withall to ≈øowe underneath their elbowes: how much do they ca≈øt them≈øelves beneath them≈øelves, and trample upon the royaltie of their office, that can finde in their hearts to ≈øtoope to this ≈øervility? A Lacedaemonian ≈ølave ≈øtanding to be ≈øold in
the market, and asked of a chapman, what Art he knew?

I am a free man, ≈øaid he: and ≈øhall Gods Amba≈ø≈øadors bee the greate≈øt ≈ølaves, who≈øe very ≈øpeech being but attired and attended (as they ought to be) with that maje≈øty and authority, which Divine truths carry in their very countenance, ≈øhould command as much reverence, as the Pontificall garments, in which Iuddus the high Prie≈øt met with Alexander the Great, who was ≈øo affected with that augu≈øte ≈øtate, and bravery of them, that he fell downe at his feet, and wor≈øhipped him, as Io≈øephus records. I have done with the in≈øtructions: a word or two of incouragement.

I will not be ≈øo bold my ≈øelfe, but I would commend any thing, to ≈øome that were worthy to put our great Rabbins in mind, wherein their honour lies: it is not Silks, nor Velvets, nor Scarlet, nor a goodly traine (what doe I ≈øpeake of the≈øe) it is not Throns, nor Dominations, nor Powers, nor any dignities, that can make a man ≈øo truly honourable, as the preaching of the Go≈øpell to poore ≈øoules, to be Gods Amba≈ø≈øadors, ≈øurely they are mi≈øtaken, they need not feare, the frequency in this duty, ≈øhould prove a di≈øparagement or imminution to greatne≈ø≈øe. Excellently ≈øaith our Saviour, All power is given unto me both in Heaven and Earth: I will now prefer all my ≈øervants, and make you Lords and Rulers, but wot yee how? it followes, Go preach to all Nations, but
this, by the way. I conclude this with a word to ≈øome, with whom I may be bold. Let no man here that is in a way to the Mini≈øtery, believe the fal≈øe ≈øpies that rai≈øe an ill report upon that good land, that flowes with milk and honey. I will ≈øay no more now, but is it thinke you a ba≈øe thing and ≈øordid, to be Amba≈ø≈øadors to the King of Heaven? I will repeat it once more, becau≈øe I can ≈øcarce heare without ≈øome indignation, that that ≈øhould be a maxime in the worlds Heraldrie, for earthly Kings, once Amba≈ø≈øador, ever honourable: And it is a ba≈øe thing to be Amba≈ø≈øadors for the King of Heaven. And now I come to the third deduction, concerning the people, which I mu≈øt run over. I ≈øhall not need to tell you, that you mu≈øt not offer any di≈øcourte≈øie to the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors: Amba≈ø≈øadors are inviolable by the law of Nations: and the Lord hath ≈øet a better mark then Cain had, and given them a better pa≈øport, touch not mine annointed, and do my Prophets no harm: And if any ≈øhould ri≈øe up again≈øt them, I would tell them boldly, what one whi≈øpered in the Captains eare, when he was ≈øomthing too bu≈øie with Paul, Take heed what thou doe≈øt, this man is a Romane: Take heed what thou doe≈øt, this man is an Amba≈ø≈øador. The Romans ≈øacked the famous Corinth and razedit to the ground, for a little di≈øcourte≈øie they offer'd to their Amba≈ø≈øadors: And what ≈øhall the Lord of the Vineyard doe to tho≈øe husbandmen, that beat and ≈øton'd
and killd his ≈øervants, that he ≈øends unto them? It is a ≈øymptome of a di≈øordered and de≈øperate e≈øtate. When the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors are violated, we pull all Gods judgements upon our heads, with the chaines of our ≈øinnes: but this is the linke of the chaine that immediately drawes them. It is a remarkable place, in the la≈øt of the Chronicles, Moreover all the chiefe of the Prie≈øts and the people tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed very much after all the abominations of the Heathen, and polluted the hou≈øe of the Lord, that he hallowed at Ieru≈øalem: here be many links, but ob≈øerve that followes, And the Lord God of their Fathers ≈øent to them by his Me≈ø≈øengers, ri≈øing up betimes and ≈øending, becau≈øe he had compa≈øsion on his people, and on his dwelling place. But they mocked the me≈øsengers of God, and de≈øpi≈øed his words, and mi≈øu≈øed his Prophets (this is the la≈øt linke, and ye ≈øee judgement fa≈øtned, chained, and linked to it) untill the wrath of the Lord aro≈øe again≈øt his people, till there was no remedie. Therefore he brought upon them the Chaldees, &c. I pa≈ø≈øe from this. When Ehud told the King of Moab, I have a Me≈ø≈øage to thee from God, O King, he ro≈øe from his thron and bowed him≈øelf. I think it was Francis that ≈øaid, if he ≈øhould meet a Preacher and an Angell together, he would fir≈øt ≈øalute the Preacher, and the Angell after. I am ≈øure Paul ≈øaith of the Galathians, that they received him as an Angell of God, yea as Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and that they would have plucked out their eyes for him, how beautifull are the feet of
tho≈øe upon the mountaines that bring the glad tydings of Peace, ≈øaith the Church in the Prophet: the Spou≈øe of Chri≈øt is ≈øo humble, or mode≈øt, or both, that ≈øhee dares looke no higher then the feet, and yet ≈øhe ≈øpies beautifull, written in the very du≈øt of their feet (as you have ≈øeene a contrary word other where) and that in ≈øuch legible characters, that ≈øhe reads it afar off, before they come neare her, upon the mountaines, as though it had beene written with a Sun beame upon ≈øome Ea≈øterne hill in a goodly morning: and tho≈øe letters printed ≈øuch affection in her, that being not able to expre≈ø≈øe it by art, ≈øhee throwes down her pen≈øill, (as you have heard of the Painter) and expre≈ø≈øes it with a pa≈ø≈øion, or rather, ≈øhe ≈øhadowes that ≈øhe could not ≈øet forth in a patheticall exclamation: How beautifull are the feet of tho≈øe upon the mountaines, that bring glad tydings of peace! and what ≈øhe did in ≈øpeeches, Mary in the Go≈øpell ≈øpake in deed, ≈øhe fell downe at the feet of Chri≈øt, ≈øhe broke her box of precious ointment and powred it upon them, ≈øhe let fall a ≈øhower of more precious tears, (penitent teares are ≈øomething like to pearls, but that they are more precious) with which ≈øhe wa≈øhed them: ≈øhe wiped them with a mo≈øt precious towell, the haires of her head: me thinks the≈øe golden haires were like to threads of gold, with which Mary tyed her ≈øelf (as it were) in a true lovers knot to her be≈øt beloved Saviour. Would you know plainly what entertainment you mu≈øt
give the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors. I will tell you in a word. Give attention, credit, obedience to their words: if they thunder and lighten out of Mount Sinai, if the Lion roare, let the proude≈øt bea≈øt in the forre≈øt quake and tremble: if Mount Sion let fall her ≈øilver drops, if the ≈øilver trumpet of the Go≈øpell ≈øound peace and comfort, let the poore≈øt worm forget that he creeps upon the earth, and think he hath a title to Heaven. I know you long till I make an end, and ≈øo do I too. To conclude therefore: I wi≈øh you could forget all that hath beene ≈øpoken, and blot it out of your memory, to fa≈øten this one thing which I am now to ≈øay. Let this be our remembrance when we go to the Lords hou≈øe, I go now to heare what Gods Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øhall ≈øay unto me: they that dre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves to go with any colder or ba≈øer conceits, may well bee checked, as Caligula was wont to ≈øay tyrannically, what Antidotum contra Cae≈øarem: and that is a reall crime in them only, which was a ridiculous accu≈øation of Trebonius, Quod telum toto pectore non exceperit. Again let this be our meditation, when we returne from thence, with benefit, Ble≈ø≈øed be thou, and ble≈ø≈øed be thy coun≈øell, and ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord that ≈øent thee out to meet me this day: Surely this is a man of God, a man of Heaven: tell me, O you that are cunning lingui≈øts, did he not ≈øpeak with the tongue of Angels? was not I in heaven while I heard him? is it but an imaginary fancie? or did I
heare the more then Pythagorean harmony of the ≈øphears? His words like Soveraigne balme dropt into my wounded ≈øoule, like the ≈øweet influence of the Pleiades upon this lower world: me thought, I felt my heart (while he ≈øpake) ≈øhoot up into my eares, as it were to meet and ki≈ø≈øe the ble≈ø≈øed lips, which di≈øtilled ≈øuch gracious dew, ≈øuch golden ≈øhowres, and drinke them as the parched, and thir≈øty earth the dew of Heaven: and yet, in the ≈øweet remembrance thereof, My ≈øoule magnifieth the Lord, and my Spirit rejoyceth in God my Saviour. Ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord that hath ≈øent his Angels, (as he did to Peter) to draw me out of the dungeon of ≈øinne and mi≈øery, that hath ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors, as David did to Hanun, to comfort me. Signa Deum agno≈øco per ≈øua, Chri≈øtus adest: only Chri≈øt the

The grace of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and the love of God the Father, and the comfortable fellow≈øhip of the ble≈ø≈øed Spirit, be with all tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoules, that by the grace of God, and power of his Spirit, love the Lord Ie≈øus.

div.p: THis ver≈øe, as you ≈øee, is linked to the former, not intire of it ≈øelfe, and independent, as appeares by the fir≈øt particle, being a cau≈øall conjunction, For I determined: and it takes us by the hand, and leades us to the next ver≈øe, of which it is a rea≈øon: for,

1. There was regi≈øtred S. Pauls action, I cannot, &c. and here we have the cau≈øe rendred, which is, Paul, agens con≈øilio, his determination, I did not, for I determined. And yet we cannot ≈øtay there, for we find and another particle, as it were another ≈øtayer, to lead us yet‚ñ™ higher. And therefore, I pray give me leave to draw the whole pedegree of my Text by the line of method, that ≈øo I may lead your under≈øtanding
into the meaning of the words, with a convenient con≈øtruction, and lead my ob≈øervations out of the meaning of the words, without any violent con≈øequution. Wherein if my di≈øcour≈øe be tedious, I will make no apologie, but this, nece≈ø≈øity forced me to ≈øeeke further then my Text, and when I was entred, delight per≈øwaded me to ≈øeeke farther then I needed: yet I re≈øolved when I had done, not to trouble you with any thing in this kinde, but then it was too late, I was compelled by another nece≈ø≈øity. Wherefore I mu≈øt intreat you to accept it as it is. The Apo≈øtle Paul, like a faithfull labourer in the Lords Vineyard, had planted a Church at Corinth, and watered it with a whole yeares Preaching, as it were, ≈øhowring downe the ≈øweet dewes of Heaven upon it. After his departure, though he had both his hands full of other imployments, yet, being jealous of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of his labour, both his eyes were watchfull, if he might by any meanes further the worke he had begun: being thus de≈øirous, there could not want occa≈øion: For behold ere long, both his eares are filled with newes from Corinth; Tho≈øe of the hou≈øe of Chloe, on the one ≈øide, welwillers to the welfare of the Church, have recour≈øe to him, to informe him of ≈øome corruptions wherewith the Church was troubled: for the envious man had ≈øowne Tares among the good Seed, while the good man was a≈øleepe. Tho≈øe of the Church of Corinth, on
the other ≈øide, make repair to him to be informed in ≈øome que≈øtions, wherwth their con≈øcience was troubled: for the gracious Lord had ble≈ø≈øed the labour of his good ≈øervant in planting and watering, with a ble≈ø≈øed increa≈øe. And thus you ≈øee a double occa≈øion of writing, which makes a double argument of this golden Epi≈øtle. Concerning corruptions, to the ≈øeventh Chapter, where he fixes a tran≈øition
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , as it were a marke of his pa≈ø≈øage to the ≈øecond; which beginning there, holds on to the end of the Epi≈øtle concerning que≈øtions: Sed tran≈øeat i≈øta. The corruptions were either ≈øuch as were generally committed by all, not only permitted, as Shi≈øme, in the 4. Chapter, or permitted only by all, not generally committed, as unnaturall ince≈øt, Chapter 5. unchri≈øtian quarrels, Chapter 6. Ye ≈øee then the deformities of Corinth, over≈øpreading the whole face, and overgrowing the whole body of the Church. All the Governours were guiltie: The Preachers with their affected eloquence and ambitious affectation had rent the people in ≈øunder, from unity to mutiny, from faith to faction. The whole Presbyterie was tardie in their dutie, ince≈øt, horrible ince≈øt was among them, the ≈øhame of the Church, the ≈øcorn of the Gentiles, the ≈øcandall of the Chri≈øtians, in ce≈øt, horrible ince≈øt was among them, jetting in their ≈øtreets, and yet they ≈øee it not, or wink at it, crying to Heaven and was heard; and yet
their ≈øword ≈øleeps in his ≈øcabbard and cannot be awaked. See yet further, they are but a little handfull, hemmed in with enemies round about, who watch them with a thou≈øand eyes, and yet they cannot leave wrangling among them≈øelves, they mu≈øt needs hale one another to the judgement ≈øeates, and there in a goodly Theater ≈øet them≈øelves, Them≈øelves? nay, the Go≈øpel, the precious word of God, the joy, glory, aud jewell of a Chri≈øtian, for which, a mans life were not deare, if he bought it ≈øo: I ≈øay, they ≈øet the Go≈øpell to ≈øale, to the deri≈øion of the Heathen. The≈øe then were the maladies of Corinth, Schi≈øme broken out with arrogancie, and not bound up with humility: Ince≈øt committed by villany, and not controlled by authority: law≈øutes pro≈øecuted at Heathen courts, and not taken up with Chri≈øtian care: and Paul like a skilfull Phy≈øitian, applies Do≈øes to the≈øe di≈øea≈øes. Ince≈øt mu≈øt be cured by cutting; Chri≈øtian caution, may prevent unchri≈øtian contention: but Schi≈øme is a longer task; that ≈øwelling humour of pride and vaine-glory, mu≈øt be aba≈øed and abated with the ≈øpare diet of a ≈øingle mind, a ≈øimple meaning, and a ≈øyncere manner in the Preaching of the Word, that ≈øo the glory of God may be advanced, and all the pride of man trampled in the du≈øt.

1. It remaines now then that we ≈øhould cleare the other, that he is the Scope of all the Scripture: which I will do fir≈øt in generall, and ≈øo leade you on into the particulars. In generall, this may be demon≈øtrated, by that which hath been before delivered: for if faith in Christ be the Epitome of the Rule of Divinitie, then needs mu≈øt it be ≈øo likewi≈øe of the

1. As the immutable ≈øub≈øtance of the Rule is con≈øidered, the ≈øub≈øtance was alway that which leads man to eternall Salvation, which is by Chri≈øt Ie≈øus only: and this is the maine ≈øcope of the Scripture in generall.

2. This is the fir≈øt proportion we find between them: the ≈øecond offers it ≈øelfe to your con≈øideration, as the Scripture may be accommodated to the mutable circum≈øtances of the Rule, according to the difference of time before and after Christ.
